title: AB 1847
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature amended Section 19851 of the Revenue and Taxation Code to address the low participation rate in the federal Earned Income Tax Credit program, resulting in unclaimed federal dollars by working poor families in California. In 2015, California authorized a state EITC to enhance the poverty-reducing impact of the federal EITC for the poorest working Californians. To alleviate the tax burden on working poor persons and families in California, the state will provide information on federal and state earned income tax credits to help them claim these credits on their tax returns and boost their wages and income. The act aims to assist eligible taxpayers by providing notices from employers and state agencies about the EITC, and ensuring Californians claim both federal and state EITC. The Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to define terms like "employer" for this purpose. The act defines terms like "employer" and "employee" in relation to unemployment insurance and EITC, including the Federal EITC and California EITC. The California EITC is defined as the earned income tax credit in California. State departments and agencies that serve those eligible for the federal EITC and California EITC include programs like free or reduced-price meals, California Unemployment Insurance, and the Medi-Cal program. Section 19853 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to require employers to notify employees about eligibility for federal and California EITC when providing annual wage summaries. State departments and agencies must inform program recipients annually about potential eligibility for federal and California EITC, either between January and April or during regular contact via phone, mail, electronic communication, or in-person. Communication can also be indirect through other agencies or districts. State departments and agencies can inform program recipients about federal and California EITC eligibility indirectly through other agencies, districts, or regulated entities serving eligible individuals. Effective methods of providing notice are encouraged as long as the language is consistent with the required notice. The employer must provide notification to the employee either in person or by mail, including instructions on obtaining IRS and Franchise Tax Board notices and information on California EITC. Additionally, the employer can create their own notice as long as it contains similar language to the required notices. The employer must provide notification to the employee in person or by mail, including instructions on obtaining IRS and Franchise Tax Board notices and information on California EITC. The employer can create their own notice with similar language to the required notices. Posting on an employee bulletin board or sending through office mail does not satisfy the notification requirement. Amendments to this section apply to notices furnished on or after the effective date of the act. Section 19854 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended. Section 19854 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to require employers to notify employees about the availability of federal and California EITC. Based on your annual earnings, you may be eligible for the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) from the federal government. The EITC is a refundable federal income tax credit for low-income working individuals and families. It does not affect certain welfare benefits like Medicaid, Supplemental Security Income, food stamps, low-income housing, or temporary assistance for needy families. Even if you don't owe federal taxes, you must file a federal tax return to receive the EITC. Fill out the EITC form in the federal income tax return booklet for more information on eligibility. To receive the federal Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC), file a federal tax return and complete the EITC form in the federal income tax return booklet. Contact the Internal Revenue Service for information on eligibility and necessary forms at 1-800-829-3676 or visit www.irs.gov. The California Earned Income Tax Credit (California EITC) is available starting from the 2015 tax year for low-income working individuals and families. It is a refundable state income tax credit that does not affect eligibility for welfare benefits. To claim the California EITC, file a California income tax return and complete the California EITC form (FTB 3514). For more information on eligibility and how to obtain the necessary forms, visit the California tax website. To claim the California Earned Income Tax Credit (California EITC), file a California income tax return and complete form FTB 3514. For more information and assistance, contact the Franchise Tax Board at 1-800-852-5711 or visit www.ftb.ca.gov. The amendments made to this section by the act adding this subdivision will apply to notices provided on or after the effective date of that act.
